bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 12, 1928

div1.p: Agramonte appreciates Kean's balanced report of the yellow fever work. He comments on current yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 12, 1928
div1.opener:
DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE
CALLE K. ENTRE 15 Y 17
VEDADO, HABANA Mar 12th, 1928
Col. J. R. Kean, U.S. Army, Ret.
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Col. Kean:
div1.p:
It has been a great pleasure to me to read the
report made by you to the Committee on Military Affairs, upon
the Copeland-Wainwright Bill. Please accept my heart-felt thanks
for the kind and just manner in which you handle that part
referring to my connection witht the Army Board's work.

I had knowledge of this Bill since March and always thought
that it was rather illogical in rewarding the men who had already
been paid for their part, in the same measure as the Members of
the Board who had received no special reward for theirs; but,
of course, it was not my place to meddle in the matter, which,
after all may have a more political that philanthropic spirit.

When the pension was proposed for Mrs. Wood in our Congress,
it did not meet with a single dissenting vote. We must recognize, how-
ever, that as far as generosity and open-heartedness is concerned, the
Nordic cannot compare with the Latin character. I, also, have my
doubts as to the Bill becoming a Law at any time, much as such
a thing would mean to me.

At the meeting of the American College of Physicians, (New
Orleans, March 5th to 10th,) I gave an address that received an
ovation, the evening of the fifth, upon a “Review of Yellow-fever
Research” and on the ninth I read a paper (“Considerations upon
the Etiologic Agent in Yellow fever”) in which I laid Noguchi's
leptospira in its grave, alongside of Sanarelli's bacillus and
Seidelins Pyroplasma. The work of Stokes, Bauer and Hudson, in
West Africa, where they have done with Asiatic monkeys what we
did with our human subjects, without finding leptospira icteroi-
des, is most conclusive. Dr. Stokes must have died from an acci-
dental mosquito bite, the insect having been in-
fected either from the experimental monkeys or from a case of
yellow fever. Blood, unless purposely sent into the circulation,
will not produce infection; otherwise, “fomites” would be infect-
ive and nobody can accept that now, I am sure.

It will please you to know that, while in New Orleans, I re-
ceived the Degree of Doctor of Laws from Tulane University; also
a gold placque, from the N. O. Association of Commerce and a life
membership. Everybody was extraordinarily kind and made my stay
in the Gulf City a never-to-be-forgotten week.
With best wishes, I remain, gratefully,
